title: How much did bread cost in the Middle Ages? - Quora

response.answer_text: The medieval era lasted for almost 500 years and spanned across Europe and the Middle East. The prices of many different goods changed drastically as the supply and demand soared or fell. Firstly, bread was the staple in Medieval Europe (as it is now as well) and thus could be found anywhere and everywhere across Europe. Many farmers grew grain and thus the supply was relatively high. However, during periods of famine, disease or war the prices of even the simplest goods may soar or drop really low. Foods for example, had a super high price during famines but a relatively lower price during disease as there were less demand for them (a lot of dead people). Many people used barter instead of money because it was more efficient and easier to trade goods. The average worker during the medieval time period earned around a penny a day and around 2 pounds per annum ( I have the currency explanation below). These wages would change dramatically according to the year however. During wars and famine, they would earn less and need to pay more but during large diseases they could expect to earn more and spend less for goods ( this was because of less demand and more supply). Some peasants, however, did not earn money, they would work for their land lord in return for food and housing, but most did earn some form of money. What I am trying to say is that the prices of anything are hard to calculate so far back in time. This has, however, not stopped people from trying to find out. Even the currency was complicated back then, to explain how much anything is worth you need to understand the money.  1 pound (L) = 20 shillings (s)  1 crown = 5 shillings  1 shilling = 12 pence (d)  1 penny = 4 farthings  1 mark = 13s 4d. I know this is a lot to take in, but it is fascinating how complicated and advanced their currency was when you understand it, just understand that the penny was the basic unit of currency. I will show you guys the prices of some basic goods. Wines could cost anywhere from between 4 pence and 8 pence per galon depending on the quality and availability. Ale could range from 0.75 to around 1.5 per gallon. Dried fruits could go for around 1-4 pence per pound. 80 pounds of cheese could go for 3 shillings and 4 pence. These are some examples, and I'm sorry I did not list bread because I couldn't find the exact pricing anywhere. However it would most likely cost around 2-3 pence per loaf.  This is a complicated question and thus this  answer may also be complicated,  and I may have made some mistakes (Many I think;)) so feel free to correct me!  These are some awesome website and PDFs which you could visit if you want to know more about the subject and the pricing of other items. Thanks for reading! http://medieval.ucdavis.edu/120D/Money.html https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/15748/1/MPRA_paper_15748.pdf

That of course varies over the millennium which makes up the period. Plus, some people were paid bread as part of their wages, so you can only guess the equivalent financial cost. The first actual statement of bread prices we have from France is in Charlemagne’s statutes of 794: “If one wants to sell [grain] as bread, twelve loaves of wheat, each of two pounds, must be given for one denier... fifteen of rye, of two pounds each, twenty of barley, of two pounds each, twenty five of oats, of two pounds each.” FRENCH BREAD HISTORY: Early medieval bread But of course then you have to look at the relative value of a denier (a silver coin). In 1268, Parisian statutes defined bread as being worth a denier, two deniers (a doubleau) and a half (demie). But since the statute says nothing about the weight (it was undoubtedly a white wheat bread), we can only guess (from later information) that it was probably under a pound. The Scots too used a system of Assizes which is somewhat more clearly explained here:Prices, Food and Wages in Scotland, 1550-1780 Similar records exist for Dublin, as well. The basic answer to your question is, “it depended”. Largely on the price of grain at a given moment, which in turn depended on abundance or famine, but also the degree of profit local authorities allowed.
